Chapter 8, Part 2: Distinguishing the Meritorious Qualities Arisen from the Meditative Absorptions in Dependence on the Meditative Absorptions, Having Thus Explained the Meditative Absorptions That Are the Basis, We Should Discuss the Meritorious Qualities That Arise in Dependence on the Meditative Absorptions.
Among the Meritorious Qualities, We First Explain the Immeasurables.
Verse:
There Are Four Kinds of Immeasurables, Because They Counteract Hatred and So Forth.
Loving-Kindness and Compassion Have the Nature of Non-Hatred, Joy Has Joy, and Equanimity Has Non-Greed.
Their Modes of Activity Are, in Sequence, Bestowing Happiness, Delivering from Suffering,
Rejoicing in Sentient Beings Being Equal, and Equanimity.
Joy Is in the First Two Meditations, the Others Are in Six or Fifty.
They Cannot Eliminate the Defilements, and Humans Generate Them. The Absorptions Definitely Accomplish Three.
The Treatise States:
There Are Four Immeasurables, Namely Loving-Kindness, Compassion, Joy, and Equanimity.
As for the Immeasurables, They Take Immeasurable Sentient Beings as Objects, They Attract Immeasurable Merit, and They Evoke Immeasurable Fruits.
Why are there only four?
Because they are antidotes to the four kinds of obstacles.
What are the four obstacles?
They are anger and malice, lack of sympathy, sensual desire and hatred.
They are established in order to counteract these.
Impurity and equanimity both counteract sensual desire. What is the difference between them?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Sensual desire is twofold: desire for form and sexual desire. Impurity and equanimity are able to counteract them in order.
In reality, impurity is able to counteract sexual desire, and equanimity is able to counteract desire for other things, such as friends.

The first two of the four immeasurables are essentially nonhatred. In reality, compassion should be said to be nonharming, joy is the feeling of joy, and equanimity is noncraving. If they are considered together with their retinue, they are composed of the five aggregates.
If equanimity is by nature noncraving, how can it counteract hatred?
Because hatred to be eliminated by it is attracted and generated by craving. In reality, it should be composed of two dharmas.
The specific characteristics of these four immeasurables are as follows. How can we cause all sentient beings to obtain such happiness?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of kindness.
How can we cause all sentient beings to be free from such suffering?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of compassion.
It would be delightful if all sentient beings could obtain happiness and be free from suffering!
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of joy.
All sentient beings are equal and impartial, without any distinction of friend or foe.
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of equanimity.
These four immeasurables cannot actually cause others to obtain happiness, etc. How can they not be mistaken?
Because one wishes to cause them to obtain happiness, etc., or because the intention is not mistaken, and because they arise in association with the thought of resolve.
Even if they are mistaken, what harm is there?
If they should not be good, the principle is not so, because they arise in association with the roots of goodness.
If it is said that it should attract evil, this is not reasonable, because it has the power to cure hatred and so on.
It takes as objects all sentient beings of the realm of desire, because it is able to cure the obstacles of hatred and so on that have them as objects.
However, a scripture says,
â€œCultivating loving-kindness, etc., one thinks of all the worlds in one direction.â€
This scripture mentions the container world in order to show the sentient beings in the container world.
The third is based only on the first two meditations, because it is categorized as the feeling of satisfaction, and it does not exist in other stages of samÄdhi.
The remaining three are common to six stages, namely, the four fundamental meditations, the intermediate, and the prefatory meditation stages.
Some people hold that they are only in five stages, excluding the prefatory stage, because they are qualities of ease and can only be produced by one who is free from desire.

Some people hold that these four immeasurables are common to ten stages, as appropriate, namely, the fundamental four meditations, the prefatory and intermediate concentrations, because they intend to have the fundamental and the preparatory stages, whether or not they are in samÄdhi, included in the immeasurables.

Although it is said that it can cure the four obstacles, it cannot cause the passions to be eliminated, because it is included in the fundamental concentrations that still have impurities, because it is associated with the attention of resolve, and because it has as its object all sentient beings.
It is said that in the state of added effort it subdues such things as hatred, or it can cause the passions that have already been eliminated to be further removed.

It is said that it can cure the four obstacles, because there is also loving-kindness, etc., in the realm of desire and the preliminary concentration, which are similar to the fundamental immeasurables that are cultivated.

Consequently, after it has subdued such obstacles as hatred, it attracts the path of elimination that can eliminate the passions. After the passions have been eliminated, one obtains the four fundamental immeasurables in the state of separation from the passions.
Even though one encounters strong conditions in the state subsequent to this, one is not covered and subdued by such things as hatred.
How does one cultivate loving-kindness in the state of first practicing?

It is said that one first reflects on the happiness that one has received oneself, or one hears it explained that Buddhas, bodhisattvas, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas receive happiness, and one then thinks:
May all sentient beings equally experience such happiness.

If their afflictions are originally intense and they are unable to generate such an impartial mind, they should divide sentient beings into three categories: close friends, neutral persons, and enemies.
Close friends are further divided into three: superior, middling, and inferior.
The neutral category is only one.
Enemies are also divided into three: inferior, middling, and superior, totaling seven categories.
After dividing the categories, one should first generate true and sincere resolve to bring happiness to the superior close friend.
When this resolve is accomplished, one should gradually cultivate such resolve towards the middling and inferior close friends.

When equality is attained towards the three categories of close friends, one should next gradually cultivate such resolve towards the middling and inferior enemies, and the superior enemy, and by the power of repeated practice, one can generate the resolve to bring happiness to the superior enemy equally as towards the superior close friend.

When this kind of resolve is cultivated and no longer regresses, then next, in regard to the object, gradually cultivate and expand it. That is, gradually extend the thought to one village, one country, one direction, and all worlds, and the characteristics of the practice of bestowing happiness are everywhere. This is the accomplishment of the perfection of loving-kindness.

If one who seeks the virtues of sentient beings is able to cultivate the samÄdhi of loving-kindness, it will be quickly accomplished. It is not for one who seeks the faults of sentient beings, because one who severs the roots of good has virtues that can be recorded, and pratyekabuddhas have faults that can be taken. This is because the fruits of former blessings and offenses are presently evident.
The methods of cultivating compassion and sympathetic joy should be understood in the same way.

That is, contemplating sentient beings drowning in the ocean of suffering, one vows that they may all attain liberation, and imagining sentient beings attaining happiness and being free from suffering, one deeply rejoices, truly considering it to be happiness.
When cultivating equanimity, one initially arises from the neutral state, gradually extending it until one can give rise to an impartial mind toward one's superior, equal, and inferior friends.
These four immeasurables are produced by humans, not by others. When one obtains one, one necessarily accomplishes three kinds.
Because one born in the third concentration, etc., does not accomplish joy.
Having explained the immeasurables, next we explain the liberations.
The verse states:
There are eight kinds of liberations, the first three have the nature of non-greed,
two are two, one is one concentration, the four are the wholesome of the formless concentrations,
the liberation of the cessation of sensation and conceptualization arises from the subtle and very subtle,
from the pure thought of one's own stage and from the undefiled of a lower stage,
the three objects are visible in the desire realm, the four objects are the category of the path,
the suffering, accumulation, and cessation of one's own and higher stages, the cessation without discrimination, and space.
The treatise states:
There are eight liberations:

The first is the liberation of internally having the concept of form while observing external forms. The second is the liberation of internally having no concept of form while observing external forms. The third is the liberation of the purity of the body, which is the realization of the fourth dhyana. The four formless concentrations are the next four liberations. The concentration of the cessation of ideation and sensation is the eighth liberation.
Among the eight, the first three have non-greed as their nature, because they are close to the antidote of greed.
However, the sutras say that they are conceptualizations and observations, because conceptualization and observation increase.
Among the three, the first two are transformations of the aspect of impurity, because they take on the aspects of blue, rotting, etc.
The third liberation is a transformation of the aspect of purity, because it is a transformation of the aspect of pure radiance.
The three, together with their assistants, all have the nature of the five aggregates.
The first two liberations are both based on the first two trances, because they can cure the greed of the realm of desire and the first trance for the manifestation of form.
The third liberation is based on the latter trance, because it is free from the eight calamities and the mind is clear and pure.
In other stages there are similar liberations, but they are not established, because they are not superior.
The next four deliverances are, in the order in which they appear in the scriptures, by nature the four good minds of the formless realm.
They are not indeterminate or defiled, because they are not deliverances.
They are also not good of the class of good that is scattered, because their nature is weak.
The good that is scattered is like the mind at the moment of death.
Some say that
it also exists at other times.
The path of deliverance of the stage of the proximate faculties is also called deliverance.
The uninterrupted path is not so, because it has a lower stage as object.
Because it is necessary to turn oneâ€™s back on the lower stage in order to be called deliverance.
However, in other places, it is generally said that only the fundamental stage is called deliverance, because the proximate faculties are not completely developed.
The eighth deliverance is the samÄdhi of cessation. Its nature, etc., have already been explained above.
Because it is produced by disgust with and turning away from feelings and conceptualization, or because it generally turns away from having an object, this samÄdhi of cessation is called deliverance.
Some say that
this deliverance is manifested after the mind of subtle activity, because it is the antidote to the obstacle of samÄdhi.
The prior stage of subtle mind is already called subtle, and this is even more subtle, hence it is called very subtle.

Next, this kind of mind enters the attainment of cessation. Emerging from the attainment of cessation, either a pure mind of the peak of existence is produced, or a pure mind of the sphere of nothingness is produced.
This kind of mind of entry is only contaminated, and it emerges from both contaminated and pure minds.
Among the eight, the first three only take the form realm of the desire realm as their objects.
There is a difference in that the objects of the first two are detestable, while the objects of the third are lovable.

The next four liberations each take as their objects the truths of suffering, origination, and cessation of their own and higher stages, and the path of the class of subsequent cognition of all stages, their non-analytical cessation, and space.
Why is there no liberation in the third meditative absorption?
Because there is no craving for form in the third meditative absorption, and because it is agitated by the wonderful bliss of its own stage.
For what reason do practitioners cultivate the liberation of purity?
It is in order to cause the mind to temporarily experience joy.
The previous contemplation of impurity caused the mind to sink and become depressed. Now, by cultivating the contemplation of purity, one encourages and delights the mind.
Or, it is in order to ascertain one's own ability, thinking, Have I accomplished or not accomplished the liberation of impurity that I previously cultivated?
If one contemplates pure characteristics and afflictions do not arise, then they have been accomplished.
For two reasons, yogis cultivate the liberations and so forth: first, to make the already severed afflictions even more distant;

second, to attain supreme mastery in samÄdhi, thus able to give rise to such qualities as non-conflict and the holy supernormal powers. By this, one is able to transform various things and perform various functions such as retention, abandonment, and so forth.
Why does the sÅ«tra say that the third and eighth are realized by the body, and not the other six?
Because these two are superior among the eight, and because they are at the end in the two realms.
Having explained the liberations, next we explain the spheres of mastery.
A verse says:
There are eight spheres of mastery, the first two are like the first liberation,
The next two are like the second, and the last four are like the third.
The treatise says:
There are eight kinds of mastery:

1. Having the notion of form internally, one sees few external forms. 2. Having the notion of form internally, one sees many external forms. 3. Without the notion of form internally, one sees few external forms. 4. Without the notion of form internally, one sees many external forms. Without the notion of form internally, one sees external blue, yellow, red, and white, making four. Together with the previous, there are eight.
Among the eight, the first two are like the first liberation, the next two are like the second liberation, and the last four are like the third liberation.
If so, how are the eight masteries different from the three liberations?

The previously cultivated liberations can only abandon and turn away, while the later cultivated masteries can control the objects of perception and, according to one's desire to contemplate, afflictions will never arise.
Having explained the masteries, next we explain the bases of totality.
The verse says:
There are ten bases of totality, eight are like the pure liberations,
The last two are the pure formless [concentrations], taking the four aggregates of their own stage as objects.
The treatise says:

There are ten all-pervading bases, namely, the all-pervading observation of earth, water, fire, wind, blue, yellow, red, white, and the two formless realms of infinite space and infinite consciousness.
They are called all-pervading bases because one observes all places without any gaps.
The first eight of the ten are like the pure liberations, that is, their intrinsic natures are all non-greed.
If they are accompanied by their assistants, their natures are the five aggregates. They are based on the fourth trance state and have as objects visible forms of the desire realm that can be seen.
Other masters say:

Only the all-pervading base of wind has as its object the wind element among the things that are touched. The last two all-pervading bases have as their intrinsic natures the two pure formless realms of space and consciousness, respectively. Each has as its object the four aggregates of its own stage.

You should know that among these, the practitioner of meditation enters the various bases of mastery from the various liberations, and enters the various all-pervading bases from the various bases of mastery, because the latter are superior to the former.
By what means are the three kinds of qualities of these liberations, etc., obtained?
On what kind of body are they based?
The verse states:
The cessation concentration is as previously explained. The others are all attained through both.
The formless [absorptions] rely on the three realms, the others only arise in the human realm.
The treatise states:
The eighth liberation has already been explained, because it is the same as the previous cessation concentration.
The remaining liberations and so forth are attained through both detachment and practice, because there is both familiar and unfamiliar [practice].
Each of the four formless liberations and two formless universal bases relies on the body of the three realms to arise, the others only arise in the human realm.
Due to the power of the teachings, both ordinary beings and sages are able to manifest them.
Those who are born in the form and formless realms give rise to the concentrations and formless [absorptions]. By what specific conditions?
The verse states:
In the two realms, due to causes and karma, one is able to give rise to the formless concentrations.
In the form realm, one gives rise to the concentrations, also due to the power of inherent nature.
The treatise states:
In general, beings of the two upper realms advance and induce the samÄdhi of the formless realm by means of three conditions:
First, by the power of causes, that is, by the power of causes that are near and frequently cultivated.

Second, by the power of karma, that is, by the power of karma that will produce a rebirth in a higher realm and whose results will be experienced later. The power of that karma is able to cause one to advance and produce that samÄdhi.
Because if one has not yet eliminated the passions of a lower realm, one definitely will not be able to be reborn in a higher realm.
Third, by the power of dharmas as they naturally are, that is, when the receptacle world is about to perish, beings of the lower realms naturally are able to produce the samÄdhi of the upper realms.
Because at this time all good dharmas increase and flourish by the power of dharmas as they naturally are.

Those who are reborn in the two upper realms and produce the samÄdhi of the formless realm do so by the power of causes and karma, not by the power of dharmas as they naturally are, because the heavens of the Ä€bhÄsvara and above are not destroyed by the three calamities.
Those who are reborn in the realm of form and produce the samÄdhi of the realm of form do so by the above two conditions and by the power of dharmas as they naturally are.
If one is born in the desire realm and gives rise to the upper concentrations, one should understand that each is due to the power of teaching.
The various Dharma gates that have been distinguished so far are all for the sake of propagating and upholding the World-Honored One's true Dharma.
What is the true Dharma?
How long will it endure?
Verse:
The Buddha's true Dharma has two aspects, namely the teachings and realization.
As long as there are those who uphold, recite, and practice, it will remain in the world.
Commentary:
The essence of the World-Honored One's true Dharma is of two kinds: first, the teachings; second, realization.

The teachings refer to the sutras, vinaya, and abhidharma; realization refers to the factors of enlightenment of the Three Vehicles.ğŸ”½As long as there are those who are able to uphold and recite the Buddha's true teachings, the Buddha's true Dharma will remain in the world.
As long as there are those who are able to practice in accordance with the teachings, the Buddha's true realization will remain in the world.
Therefore, one should know that the duration of the true Dharma is equal to the length of time that these three types of people remain in the world.

The scriptures in general say that they will last for a thousand years. Some explain that the evidence of the Dharma will last for a thousand years, and the teaching of the Dharma will last even longer than this.
This treatise relies on the Abhidharma, but on what principle does it explain the Abhidharma?
Verse:
The reasoning established by the KÄÅ›mÄ«ri scholars is correct, and I rely on them mostly in explaining the Abhidharma.
There are a few criticisms, which are my faults. The correct principle of judging dharmas lies with the Sage.
Discussion:

The reasoning established by the KÄÅ›mÄ«ri VaibhÄá¹£ika scholars in discussing the Abhidharma is well-founded. I rely on them mostly in explaining the Abhidharma school, with a few criticisms, which are my faults.
The correct principle of judging dharmas lies solely with the World-Honored One and the great sages and disciples of the TathÄgatas.
The great teacher, the eye of the world, has long since closed, and many of those who could serve as witnesses have dispersed.
Not seeing the truth, without restraint, they confuse the holy teachings with their contemptible speculations.
Having realized and returned to the supreme tranquility, many who uphold his teachings follow in extinction,
The world loses its support and is deprived of many virtues, without the hook to control, afflictions arise as one pleases.
Knowing that the lifespan of the TathÄgata's true Dharma, gradually perishes like reaching the throat,
When the power of these afflictions increases, one should seek liberation and not be negligent.
How can there be liberation?
Reasonably, there must be none.
Why is it so?
Because it is deluded by the false grasping of self.
It is said that the self grasped by those outside this teaching, is not merely the designation of the continuity of the aggregates, because it is grasped as a real self separate from the aggregates.
Due to the power of grasping the self, the afflictions arise, and one wanders in the three existences without the possibility of liberation.
What is the evidence for this?ğŸ”½It is known that the term self only refers to the continuity of the aggregates, not to a separate self-nature.
In the self conceived as separate from the aggregates, there is no real direct perception or inference.
If the self is a real entity that is different from other dharmas,
if there are no obstacles to its conditions, it should be perceived by direct perception, like the six objects of perception, or by inference, like the five material organs.

As for the five material organs being perceived by inference, it is like what is seen in the world: even though there are many conditions, if a specific condition is lacking, the result does not exist, but if it is not lacking, then it does exist, like a seed producing a sprout.

In the same way, it is also seen that even though there are conditions such as the present object and attention, the consciousness of the blind and deaf does not arise, while that of those who are not blind or deaf does arise. It is certain that there is a specific condition that is lacking or not lacking.
This specific condition is the eye and other organs. This is called the inference of the material organs.
The two means of valid cognition do not exist at all in regard to a self apart from the aggregates. Therefore, it is proven that there is no real self.
However, the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«ya school holds that there is a pudgala, whose substance is neither the same as nor different from the aggregates.
This should be investigated: is it real or nominal?
What are the characteristics of real existence and nominal existence?
The characteristic of real existence is that there are separate things, like form, sound, etc.
The characteristic of nominal existence is that there is only aggregation, like milk, curd, etc.
What is the error in asserting real existence and what is the error in asserting nominal existence?
If the substance is real, it must be different from the aggregates, because it has a separate nature, like the separate aggregates.
Moreover, if there is a real substance, it must have a cause, or it must be unconditioned, and then it would be the same as the non-Buddhist view.
Moreover, it would be useless, and it would be in vain to grasp at real existence.
If the substance is nominal, then it would be the same as what I say.
The pudgala that I posit is not like what you ask about, whether it is really existent or nominally existent?
One can only posit pudgala based on the present aggregates that are appropriated internally and included in the present.
Such a mistaken statement does not yet clarify the meaning.
I still do not understand, what do you mean by based on?

If the meaning of basis is that it is a collection of aggregates, then since the person is a collection of aggregates, the person would be a provisional existent, like milk, yogurt, and so on, which are collections of form and so on.
If the meaning of basis is that it is a cause of the aggregates, then since the person is a cause of the aggregates, the person would also have this fault, but it is not established in this way.
How is it established?
It is like the worldâ€™s positing fire as dependent on fuel. How is fire posited as dependent on fuel?
It is not possible to posit fire apart from fuel, but fuel and fire are neither different nor the same.
If fire were different from fuel, fuel would not be hot.
If fire were the same as fuel, the burned would be the same as the burner.
In the same way, the person is not established apart from the aggregates.

However, the person and the aggregates are neither different nor the same. If it were different from the aggregates, its substance would be permanent. If it were the same as the aggregates, its substance would be annihilated.
You should now definitely explain what fire is.
What is fuel?
Cause me to understand the meaning of fire depending on fuel.
What should be said?
If it is said, it should be said that what is burned is fuel and what can burn is fire.
This should be further explained: what is burned and what can burn are called fuel and fire.
This is generally understood in the world.
All things that are not blazing and burning are called what is burned and fuel.
All things that have light, are extremely hot and blazing, and can burn are called what can burn and fire.
This can burn and ignite that continuity of things, causing the later to be different from the former.

Although this and that are both composed of eight things, fire can only arise in dependence on fuel, just as alcohol arises in dependence on milk, and vinegar arises in dependence on alcohol. Therefore, the world generally says that fire exists in dependence on fuel.
If fire is in accordance with this principle, then fire is different from fuel, because the later fire and the former fuel are each separate.

If you maintain that the pudgala is like fire, which is dependent on fuel, then you must admit that it is produced in dependence on the aggregates, that it is different from the aggregates, and that it is impermanent.

If you say that the heat element in burning wood, etc., is called fire, and the other dharmas are called fuel, then fire and fuel would be produced simultaneously and would have to be considered different from each other, because they are different from each other.
You must explain what you mean by the expression â€œdependent on fuel.â€ Since fire and fuel are produced simultaneously, how can you say that fire is dependent on fuel?
Fire does not use fuel as its cause, because they are produced simultaneously from their own causes.
Fire is not named in dependence on fuel, because the name fire is given in dependence on the heat element.

If you say that the expression â€œfire is dependent on fuelâ€ is used to show that they are produced together or that they are in a relation of support, then you must admit that the pudgala is produced together with the aggregates or that it is in a relation of support with the aggregates.

You have already clearly admitted that its substance is different from the aggregates, and you must admit that it is produced together with the aggregates or that it is in a relation of support with the aggregates.
If you admit that the aggregates do not exist, then the person does not exist, just as if firewood does not exist, fire does not exist.
But this is not admitted, so this explanation is not correct.
But they themselves raise the objection,
â€œIf fire is different from firewood, firewood would not be hot.â€
They must definitely explain what the nature of heat is.
If they explain heat as the contact of warmth, then firewood is not hot, because its nature and characteristics are different.

If they explain heat as the combination of warmth, then that which is different in substance can also be called hot, because the real name fire refers only to the contact of warmth, and the rest that combines with warmth can all be called hot.
This clearly admits that firewood is called hot.
Even though firewood and fire are different, the error is not committed. How can this be raised as a difficulty here?
If it is said that when wood, etc., is completely ablaze, it is called firewood and also called fire, then it must be explained what the meaning of basis is.
It must be admitted that the person is definitely the same as the aggregates of form, etc., and no reasoning can deny it.

Therefore, their statement that the pudgala is established in dependence on the aggregates, like fire is established in dependence on fuel, is not established by reasoning, whether considered in terms of identity or difference.

Moreover, if they admit that the pudgala is neither identical with nor different from the aggregates, then the three times, the unconditioned, and the five kinds of seeds that cannot be spoken of must also be unspeakable, because the pudgala cannot be said to be the fifth or not the fifth.
Moreover, they must clearly state what the pudgala is that they posit.
If they say that it is posited in dependence on the aggregates, the meaning of the provisional is already established, because the positing of the pudgala is not dependent on the pudgala.

If they say that this positing is dependent on the pudgala, how can they say above that it is established in dependence on the aggregates? The principle is that they should only say that it is established in dependence on the pudgala.
Since they do not admit this, it is only dependent on the aggregates.
If they say that it can be known only if there are aggregates, then I say above that it is established in dependence on the aggregates.
Therefore, all forms are only cognized when they have the conditions of the eyes, etc. Therefore, it should be said that they rely on the eyes, etc.
Moreover, it should be explained: among the six consciousnesses, which consciousness cognizes the pudgala?
It is cognized by the six consciousnesses.
Why is this?

If at one time the eye consciousness cognizes form, and because of this one knows that there is a pudgala, it is said that this is cognized by the eye consciousness, but it cannot be said to be the same as or different from form.

Up to when at one time the mental consciousness cognizes dharmas, and because of this one knows that there is a pudgala, it is said that this is cognized by the mental consciousness, but it cannot be said to be the same as or different from dharmas.
If so, the pudgala that is conceived should be the same as milk, etc., and only nominally established.

That is to say, if when the eye consciousness cognizes forms, because of this one is able to know that there is milk, etc., then milk, etc. are said to be cognized by the eye consciousness, but it cannot be said to be the same as or different from form.

When the body consciousness cognizes tangible objects, if it can know the existence of milk, etc., it can be said that milk, etc. are cognized by the body consciousness, but it cannot be said to be the same as or different from tangible objects.
Do not let milk, etc. become four or not composed of four.

For this reason, it should be established that the existence of a person is designated in dependence on the aggregates in general, just as milk, etc. are designated in dependence on form, etc. in the world. This is a designation, not a real entity.
Moreover, what they say, if at one time the eye consciousness cognizes form, because of this it knows that a person exists.
What is the meaning of these words?
Do they say that all forms are the cause of cognizing a person?
Or when form is cognized, can a person also be cognized?

If it is said that all forms are the cause of cognizing this, but it cannot be said that this is different from form, then because form is the cause of cognition by means of the eye, light, attention, etc., it should not be said that form is different from the eye, etc.
If it is cognized when form is cognized, is it cognized by the same cognition that cognizes form, or is it cognized by a separate cognition?
If it is cognized by the same cognition that cognizes form, then it should be admitted that its substance is identical with form, or that it is merely provisionally established on the basis of form.
Or else, one should not make distinctions such as this kind is form and this kind is the person.
If there are not these two kinds of distinctions, how can one establish the existence of form and the existence of a person? Because a person must be established by distinctions.

If there is a separate cognition of it, then when it is cognized, it should be different from form, just as yellow is different from blue, and the previous moment is different from the subsequent moment, and so on.
The same kind of argument can be made regarding dharmas.
If they argue that
the person and form cannot be said to be either identical or different, and the same is true of the two kinds of cognition, then cognition should not be included among conditioned dharmas.
If one admits this, then one destroys one's own doctrine.
If the pudgala really exists and cannot be said to be either material or not material, why did the World Honored One say:
